subject: Re: [junit] Running unit tests (without testsuites) with ant and eclipse
msgSnippet: Hi Mark, This is what I have used before using DynamicSuites:
messageBody:
Hi Mark,

This is what I have used before using DynamicSuites:

<junit printsummary="yes" haltonfailure="yes">
<classpath>
<pathelement location="${build.tests}"/>
<pathelement path="${java.class.path}"/>
</classpath>

<formatter type="plain"/>

<batchtest fork="yes" todir="${reports.tests}">
<fileset dir="${src.tests}">
<include name="**/*Test*.java"/>
<exclude name="**/AllTests.java"/>
</fileset>
</batchtest>
</junit>

This is a bit slow though due to fork="yes" but that gives you a clean
JVM for your tests.
There are a few solutions for suite maintainance, one of them is
having eclipse update them for you. That should look something like
this:

public class AllTests {

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("Test for com.ohlrogge.uciti.word");
//$JUnit-BEGIN$
suite.addTestSuite(TestVerbAgati.class);
suite.addTestSuite(TestVerbIti.class);
suite.addTestSuite(TestVerbEti.class);
suite.addTestSuite(TestVerbAti.class);
suite.addTestSuite(TestVerbAkati.class);
suite.addTestSuite(TestVerbAhati.class);
suite.addTestSuite(TestVerbUnknownEnding.class);
suite.addTestSuite(TestVerbSati.class);
//$JUnit-END$
return suite;
}

}

I generated it with new | other | junit | testsuite, i think that I
have seen some "update suite" option somewhere but I can't find it
again. Anyone else on the list that knows?

The option I am using now is DynamicSuites:
http://rmock.sourceforge.net/dynamicsuites.html

This resolves the suite dynamically in runtime. This is way faster
than batch-test in forked mode and allows for some creativity in
test-selection and data-driven tests.

There is also something similar in jUnitt add ons if you prefer that.

From my experience with dynamic suites i can warmly recomend that
solution and I think that I can recomend the junit add on solution
aswell although I have not tried it myself.


About plugin tests (I am assuming that you mean testing eclipse
plugins) I think that you need to run ant within eclipse headless (but
I guess you already know that). If you don't then maybe this article
can point you in the right direction:

http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-PDE-Automation/automation.html

Hope this helps.

/J

> Confused and feeling under documented
